poem:
Every Night Was Halloween  

Through the city's pulse,  
laughter spills like marbles,  
spangles and neon,  
an endless costume ball.  

Sharon's lens, a keyhole,  
captures the masquerade—  
whispers of silk,  
and thunderous hues.  

Each flicker,  
an eccentric heartbeat  
of Manhattan's vein—  
where even shadows  
dared to wear a grin.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Every night was Halloween’ – how one ‘camera girl’ captured the madcap style of 80s New York To get into the kind of club where Sharon Smith worked, in New York City during the 80s, you couldn’t just turn up in jeans and a nice top. You had to really dress. You certainly couldn’t turn up in army fatigues and a patched-up blue-jean skirt, which is what Smith had worn before becoming a “camera girl”". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
